titlePage.titlePart: Title from the title page (fol. 1r): Froodlegur Boksagna sioodur. Innehalldande Velmarga Afbragds Væna Sógu þætte, þeim til froodleiks sem þvijlijkt gyrnaz. Epter þeim Ordrettustu og Æfe ellſtu fundamentis sem til hafa feingest Wppskrifadur. Ad forlage og Vppakostnade Erugofugs Hófdingja Magnusar Joonssonar. Ad Wigur ä Ysafiardar Diwpe. Anno Domini MDCLXXXII.

support.watermark:
There are many different watermarks. The most common is a small foolscap, but a large foolscap exists as well (e.g. fol. 150), otherwise there are e.g. two different coats of arms (one smaller with crown on top, one larger without), a round watermark with a double surrounding line containing letters or numbers, a large geometrical watermark with writing underneath. On the leaves containing the illustrations, there are the following watermarks:
fol. 2: letters (GO?) in a frame
fol. 79: large foolscap
fol. 143: (unknown, because glued together with another leaf)

supportDesc.foliation: There is later foliation in red ink (partly repeated in pencil) in the upper right corner of the leaves.
There is modern foliation in pencil in the middle of the boddom margins. Sometimes, this foliation is erased.
There is foliation in black ink on cirka every tenth leaf in the lower right corner, which does not count the first leaves, including the inserted picture.

supportDesc.condition: The manuscript has been heavily repaired. Especially in the beginning and end, there are parts missing, which have been replaced during conservation. The leaves at the original quire boundaries are dirtier than inside the original quires. Some of the additions in the margins are party cut off due to trimming of the leaves.

handDesc.handNote: Magnús Þórólfsson wrote fols 3–62 and 144–288. Jón Helgason, Kvæðabók úr Vigur9.
Parts written by Þórður Jónsson á Skarði, father of Jón Þórðarson Jón Helgason, Kvæðabók úr Vigur, 9.

Jón Þórðarson á Strandseljum wrote fols 80r–143r Jón Helgason, Kvæðabók úr Vigur9. He also wrote AM 345 4to etc. The script is very upright and neat and shows some aspects of chancery. There is a characteristic stroke through slashed os and on hooked es.

decoNote.p:
There are three large paintings of the main characters of some of the sagas (cf. also additions):
Egill Skallagrímsson (2v)
Grettir Ásmundarson (79v)
Guðmundur ríki Eyjólfsson 143v)
A matching illustration of Njáll is found in Lbs 3505 4to, with a caption written byMagnús Ketilsson.
The title page is decorated and framed using red, green, yellow and blue colours. The text in written in blue and red ink.
There are large intials, which are decorated intriguingly with floral ornaments. Many of them are additionally coloured.
Rubrics and sometimes the first line of texts are coloured.
There is a tail-piece on fol. 317r inthe same style as the decoration on the title page.

decoDesc.decoNote: The end of texts was written in the shape of a half diamond.

additions.p: Marginal additios in the hand of Jón Ólafsson úr Grunnavík are found in on several pages.
Fol. 273 is an added leaf with an addition to the text on fol. 272v.

On fol. 297, there is an additional piece of paper attached to the lower margin. Judged by its dirtiness and the clean surface underneath, it can be assumed that it has been there from early on. On the same leaf, the corner is missing and was replaced during conservation. The shape of the missing part and the additional piece, however, do not match.

There are three folio-sized paint illustrations, appearently done by Hjalti Þorsteinsson, that may not have been part of the manuscript from the beginning. These are Egill Skallagrímsson on fol. 2v, which is the second part of the first bifolium but is not connected to any gathering, Grettis Ásmundarson on fol. 79v, which is a singleton leaf, and Guðmundur ríki on fol. 143v, which has been glued together with another leaf that now counted as 143r. Agnete Loth 1967, Opuscula III94–95.

Fol. 1v contains a table con contents, to which the last item Af Niaale og þeim fleirumm, er sw sagha umgietur has been added later by Magnús Ketilsson and then been crossed out again. Magnús Ketilsson also added the names on two of the illustrations: fols 2v and 143v.

binding.p: The binding is from the late eighteenth century Loth 1967, 93, according to Kålund from ca. 1770. The binding is made out of dark plain leather on thick wooden boards ( 302200700). There used to be two metal clasps of which parts are missing now. During conservation material has been removed from the binding and is now stored separately with the manuscript (cf. accMat).

accMat.p: A detailed description by Jón Sigurðsson is kept with the manuscript.

The followong material was removed from the binding and is now stored separately:
Strings.
Small strips of paper, most of them palimpsests.
A letter from 1769

origin.p: The mansucript was written in Ísafjörður, in Iceland over the years 1670–1682 (cf. colophons). It was commissioned by Magnús Jónsson í Vigur.

provenance.p: According to Kålund, the manuscript is mentioned in the oldest additament-katalog as being taken out of Árni Magnússon's house after his death (opleveret fra Magnæi stervboe) Katalog I, 318. Therefore it has been suggested that Árni Magnússon had only borrowed the manuscript and it was brought back to Iceland after his death Annette Hasle 1967 Hrafns saga Sveinbjarnarsonar. B-redaktionen. Editiones Arnamagnæanæ B, 25, XXV.
According to Agnete Loth 1967 Opuscula III 92–95 the mansucript was extended by Njáls saga (now in NKS 1220 fol.), which was later removed again.
